comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Yes! I tried to find an accordion and voice version on YouTube, but only found it in German, where it is much more popular (originally from Nova Scotia in the 1890s).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I did not know of "Rolling Home" before this reference (I have an English background as a musician), but this site with basic sheet music and words says it was the most famous homeward-bound song of them all (Stan Hugill, in 'Shanties from the Seven Seas' 1961). Like most folk songs the words get adapted by word-of-mouth etc. www.educationscotland.gov.uk/scotlandssongs/secondary/gen... "According to Hugill it was "the most famous homeward-bound shanty of all," and was popular in both English and American Ships. It is believed the shanty is based on a poem by Charles Mackay, written on board ship in 1858, but Hugill speculates that Mackay could have heard the sailors at the capstan and based his poem on the original shanty. Many collectors state the song was a forecastle song, rather than a shanty, but there are several shanty versions and Whall cites several sources which confirm it was used as a capstan shanty. " from www.youtube.com/watch?v=25uLx3uyca0 Good luck finding the truth !

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks for the links beachcomber. That's the thing with shanties isn't it? There is often speculation as to where they originated, because they were sung more than they were written down or recorded. We've posted a couple of blogs on the subject and would like to do more research as we have an extensive collection of sheet music and shanties.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
